articles.headline: Feeling Misled on Home Price, Buyers Sue Agent
articles.snippet: Many resentful buyers may seek redress from the agents who found them a home and arranged its purchase.
articles.abstract: Many resentful buyers may seek redress from the agents who found them a home and arranged its purchase.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARLSBAD, Calif.  Marty Ummel feels she paid too much for her house. So do millions of other people who bought at the peak of the housing boom.

articles.headline: Mexico Hits Drug Gangs With Full Fury of War
articles.snippet: Forces are not only hunting cartel leaders, but also going after their crews of gunslingers, who terrorize towns.
articles.abstract: Forces are not only hunting cartel leaders, but also going after their crews of gunslingers, who terrorize towns.
articles.lead_paragraph: RÍO BRAVO, Mexico  These days, it is easy to form the impression that a war is going on in Mexico. Thousands of elite troops in battle gear stream toward border towns and snake through the streets in jeeps with .50-caliber machine guns mounted on top while fighter jets from the Mexican Navy fly reconnaissance missions overhead.

articles.headline: Rangel Remains in Clinton’s Camp in Her Battle With Obama
articles.snippet: Congressman Charles B. Rangel is putting his muscle and prestige behind Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential bid, even as her standing among African-Americans is plunging.
articles.abstract: Congressman Charles B. Rangel is putting his muscle and prestige behind Hillary Rodham Clinton’s presidential bid, even as her standing among African-Americans is plunging.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last summer, a Brooklyn lawmaker ran into Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem and they began discussing the presidential race. Mr. Rangel, 77, bluntly told the younger politician that he should get on board with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.

articles.headline: In Matters Big and Small, Crossing Giuliani Had Price
articles.snippet: Far more than his predecessors, Rudolph W. Giuliani’s toughness as mayor of New York City edged toward ruthlessness.
articles.abstract: Far more than his predecessors, Rudolph W. Giuliani’s toughness as mayor of New York City edged toward ruthlessness.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani likens himself to a boxer who never takes a punch without swinging back. As mayor, he made the vengeful roundhouse an instrument of government, clipping anyone who crossed him.
articles.byline: By Michael Powell and Russ Buettner

articles.headline: What Money Can Buy: Influence
articles.snippet: While government-controlled funds swear up and down that their investments are purely financially motivated, they just can’t be.
articles.abstract: While government-controlled funds swear up and down that their investments are purely financially motivated, they just can’t be.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Why isn’t Warren Buffett making an investment in Citigroup when Kuwait is?” asked Felix G. Rohatyn, the banker who helped save New York City from bankruptcy in the 1970s.

articles.headline: In Asia, Global Market Decline Accelerates
articles.snippet: Markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Sydney on Tuesday extended the losses they suffered Monday as fears of a recession roiled markets worldwide.
articles.abstract: Markets in Tokyo, Hong Kong and Sydney on Tuesday extended the losses they suffered Monday as fears of a recession roiled markets worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid fears that the United States may be in a recession, the decline in stock markets accelerated Tuesday across Asia.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: World Markets Plunge on Fears of U.S. Slowdown
articles.snippet: Markets in Asia were down in early trading on Tuesday, a day after stock prices fell in exchanges from Mumbai to Frankfurt.
articles.abstract: Markets in Asia were down in early trading on Tuesday, a day after stock prices fell in exchanges from Mumbai to Frankfurt.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Fears that the United States may be in a recession reverberated around the world on Monday, sending stock markets from Mumbai to Frankfurt into a tailspin and puncturing the hopes of many investors that Europe and Asia would be able to sidestep an American downturn.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Obama and Clinton Tangle at Debate
articles.snippet: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama challenged each other on issues of integrity.
articles.abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama challenged each other on issues of integrity.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the most intense and personal exchange of the presidential campaign, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama assailed each other’s integrity and voting records during a televised debate on Monday in South Carolina, the site of a critical primary in five days.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: To Some, the Widening Crisis Seems Driven by Fear, Not Facts
articles.snippet: What makes the current correction dangerous, analysts say, is that selling is being driven by hedge funds and investment banks, not panicky retail investors.
articles.abstract: What makes the current correction dangerous, analysts say, is that selling is being driven by hedge funds and investment banks, not panicky retail investors.

articles.headline: Editor Fires Parting Shot at His Chain
articles.snippet: The ousted editor of The Los Angeles Times on Monday argued that cost cuts, a lack of investment and an aversion to serious news is damaging the newspaper industry.
articles.abstract: The ousted editor of The Los Angeles Times on Monday argued that cost cuts, a lack of investment and an aversion to serious news is damaging the newspaper industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ousted editor of The Los Angeles Times on Monday offered a scathing critique of the newspaper industry and specifically his longtime employer, the Tribune Company, arguing that cost cuts, a lack of investment and an aversion to serious news was damaging the business.

articles.headline: Airwaves, Web Power at Auction
articles.snippet: The auction for rights to a highly valuable swath of the nation’s airwaves will begin Thursday and is expected to include multibillion-dollar bids from the nation’s two biggest wireless phone companies.
articles.abstract: The auction for rights to a highly valuable swath of the nation’s airwaves will begin Thursday and is expected to include multibillion-dollar bids from the nation’s two biggest wireless phone companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The auction for rights to a highly valuable swath of the nation’s airwaves will begin Thursday and is expected to include multibillion-dollar bids from the nation’s two biggest wireless phone companies, Verizon and AT&T, as well as Google.

articles.headline: If Everyone’s Finger-Pointing, Who’s to Blame?
articles.snippet: The turmoil in the mortgage markets has incited a wave of legal tangles, as homeowners are suing lenders, lenders are suing banks, banks are suing loan specialists. And investors are suing everyone.
articles.abstract: The turmoil in the mortgage markets has incited a wave of legal tangles, as homeowners are suing lenders, lenders are suing banks, banks are suing loan specialists. And investors are suing everyone.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone wants to know who is to blame for the losses paining Wall Street and homeowners.
